tn.text: Ziklag is a city in the southern part of Judah. This was where David and his men kept their families.
the Amalekites
Possible meanings are 1) "both unimportant people and important people" or 2) "both physically small and physically large."
belonging to David and his men

tn.ref: it was burned, and their wives ... daughters were taken captive
tn.text: This can be translated in active form. AT: "they saw that someone had burned it and taken their wives ... captive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the people that were with him
tn.text: These were mainly his army of men.

tn.ref: all the people were bitter in spirit
tn.text: The word "bitter" is a metaphor for the desire to rebel. The word "spirit" is a synecdoche for the person. AT: "all the people were ready to rebel against David" or "all the people were very unhappy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: David strengthened himself in Yahweh, his God
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "David took courage because he knew Yahweh his God would help him" or 2) "Yahweh his God made David strong."
David seeks Yahweh's direction in dealing with the raid on his people.

tn.ref: David prayed to Yahweh for direction
tn.text: The abstract noun "direction" can be translated as a clause. AT: "David prayed that Yahweh would tell David what David should do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement: AT: "No one will listen to you in this matter." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: as the share is for anyone who goes
